supplementary_assessment.format: Supplementary exam (Deferred Final Assessment period: 4–8 August 2025)
supplementary_assessment.requirement_to_pass: Score at least 50% on supplementary exam to convert final grade to 50 P

clayton.notes: Apply online before deadline; viewing sessions will likely be midweek.

questions.feedback: Simple recurrence relation unsolvable by Master’s Theorem; required intuitive reasoning.
common_pitfalls: Lack of hands-on practice testing different recurrences.
questions.advice: Practice solving recurrences manually and test variations to develop intuition.

questions.feedback: Direct analysis similar to assignment tasks; did not require recurrence solving.
questions.advice: Focus on recursion depth and call structure; unnecessary to formalize recurrences.

questions.feedback: Straightforward analysis of time complexity, invariants, and stability.
questions.advice: Use sorting algorithms to strengthen reasoning about algorithmic properties.

questions.feedback: Relatively simple but many students got preconditions wrong (Q5).
questions.advice: Code and trace binary search manually; understand loop invariants and termination.

questions.topic: QuickSelect Algorithm and Average Case Complexity
questions.feedback: Covered correctness and average case reasoning for QuickSelect.
questions.advice: Code and step through QuickSelect to understand partition behavior and pivot selection.

questions.feedback: Rewarded reasoning about complexity changes over memorization.
questions.advice: Understand representation tradeoffs; recall that Dijkstra’s was implemented in Assignment 1.

questions.feedback: Tested understanding of MST algorithms and correctness reasoning.
common_pitfalls: Failure to justify correctness or handle variants properly.
questions.advice: Compare algorithms conceptually; trace edge inclusion logic for both Prim and Kruskal.

questions.feedback: Asked to distinguish DP and Greedy paradigms conceptually.
common_pitfalls: Failing to differentiate optimal substructure and greedy choice property.
advice: Attempt applied DP problems to identify recurrence patterns.
Create a comparison table between DP and Greedy approaches.

questions.feedback: Key insight: outer loop corresponds to intermediate vertex.
questions.advice: Trace algorithm carefully; identify iteration roles to avoid confusion.

questions.feedback: Common mistakes include missing augmenting paths or residual updates.
common_pitfalls: Neglecting backward edges in residual graphs.
questions.advice: Always draw residual networks with both forward and backward edges; practice manually.

questions.feedback: Similar to applied and quiz problems; required solid practice.
questions.advice: Be comfortable transforming circulation problems into flow networks.

questions.feedback: Common error: not identifying the correct value of k during 2k sorting.
questions.advice: Understand growth in k during iterations; visualize sorted substrings.

questions.feedback: New topic; straightforward once traced manually.
questions.advice: Perform insertion steps by hand to internalize splitting and promotion.

questions.feedback: Confusing for some; required partition reasoning.
questions.advice: Draw partitions manually to track element positioning relative to pivot.

questions.feedback: Slight variant of applied class DP question.
questions.advice: Recognize familiar DP patterns; practice small variants frequently.

questions.feedback: Required identifying the best algorithm for given situations.
questions.advice: Think comparatively; same reasoning used in technical interviews.

questions.feedback: DP problem variant similar to applied session examples.
questions.advice: Practice classical DP problems; new ones are often simple variants.

questions.feedback: Asked to compare Greedy and DP for Knapsack.
questions.advice: Understand where Greedy fails and why DP ensures optimality.

summary: Understand algorithms at a conceptual and reasoning level, not just steps.
Being a year-2 ADS unit, higher cognitive reasoning is expected.
Hands-on coding and manual tracing are the best preparation methods.
Memorization alone is insufficient; focus on understanding and application.
general_feedback.final_message: All the best, FIT2004 Teaching Team
